title: The fight for the right to vote in the United States - Nicki Beaman Griffin

multiple-choice.question: Who was the first President of the United States to win the electoral college with 100% of the vote?

What was the main issue that led to the American Civil War?

What was the main issue that led to the passage of the 26th Amendment in 1971?
What percentage of eligible voters in the United States actually vote?
What is the main challenge facing the United States in terms of voting rights today?

options.label: A
options.text: Ensuring that all citizens have the right to vote

title: Origins of religion

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people learn through experience?

options.label: A
options.text: The difference between their own spirits and the spirits of others

options.label: B
options.text: The difference between what poisoned them and what satisfied their hunger

options.label: C
options.text: The difference between their own will and the will of others

options.label: D
options.text: The difference between their own movement and the movement of others

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe would happen if they ate the flesh of a strong beast?

options.label: C
options.text: They would lose their own spirit

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe about the sun and moon?

options.label: C
options.text: They were spirits that lived in the sky

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe about the connection between their own movement and the movement of others?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed that all movement was random

options.label: B
options.text: They believed that all movement was the product of will

options.label: C
options.text: They believed that some movement was the product of will and some was random

options.label: D
options.text: They believed that only their own movement was the product of will

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe about the will of plants?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed that plants did not have will

options.label: B
options.text: They believed that plants grew because of a will within

options.label: C
options.text: They believed that plants grew because of a spirit within

options.label: D
options.text: They believed that plants grew because of magic

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe about the gods?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed that there was only one god

options.label: B
options.text: They believed that there were many gods

options.label: C
options.text: They believed that gods were spirits that lived in the sky

options.label: D
options.text: They believed that gods were created by humans

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe about the connection between fire and spirit?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed that fire was not a manifestation of spirit

options.label: B
options.text: They believed that fire was a manifestation of magic

options.label: C
options.text: They believed that fire was a manifestation of spirit

options.label: D
options.text: They believed that fire was created by humans

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe about the purpose of storytelling?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed that storytelling was used to record historical events

options.label: B
options.text: They believed that storytelling was used to describe their world in a way that they could understand

options.label: C
options.text: They believed that storytelling was used to entertain

options.label: D
options.text: They believed that storytelling was used to teach moral lessons

multiple-choice.question: What did Stone Age people believe about the possibility of changing their world?

options.label: A
options.text: They believed that they could change their world through magic

options.label: B
options.text: They believed that they could change their world through technology

options.label: C
options.text: They believed that they could change their world through social progress

options.label: D
options.text: They believed that they could not change their world

multiple-choice.question: What did the transcript suggest about the potential for modern society to appear sooner?

options.label: A
options.text: The transcript suggested that modern society would appear much later

options.label: B
options.text: The transcript suggested that modern society would appear much sooner

options.label: C
options.text: The transcript suggested that modern society would not appear at all

options.label: D
options.text: The transcript suggested that modern society would appear at the same time
